Event:
My daughter tried to kill herself again, and her husband found out and helped her get treatment.

The event in this passage is the third attempt at suicide by the daughter, which is a significant and harmful occurrence from the parent's point of view. The event is described as "trying to kill herself again" and "digging into her arm" which are clear indicators of self-harm and mental illness. The event also has an impact on the husband, who is traumatized by what he saw and is considering divorce. The parent is saddened and afraid for both their daughter and the husband, and feels powerless to help their daughter overcome her mental illness and poor choices.
Post: "I'm so grateful that my daughter's husband found out about her suicide attempt and helped her get treatment. It's a huge relief that she's safe now, but I can't help feeling devastated that she's struggling with mental illness. I wish there was more I could do to help her." #GAS #GlobalAttributionalStyle #SuicidePrevention #MentalHealthMatters

Event: Feeling sad and lonely despite being surrounded by loving family and caring friends.
Post: "Feeling like I'm stuck in a rut, like nothing is going right in my life. I'm surrounded by people who care about me, but it feels like they're all just pretending to care. Maybe I'm just not cut out for this whole 'life' thing."

Event:
...

The main event in this post is the individual's experience of depression and their recent break-up with their girlfriend. The event is described as "having depression since late Jan 2016" and "breaking up with my girlfriend (4 months)". These are two significant events that have had a negative impact on the individual's mental health and well-being.
Post:
"I've been struggling with depression since late Jan 2016, and recently broke up with my girlfriend. It feels like everything in my life is falling apart and I'm never going to be happy again."

This post exhibits a global attributional style because it takes two specific events (depression and break-up) and extrapolates them to imply that the individual's entire life is negatively impacted. It implies that the person is doomed to be unhappy forever, which is an example of a pessimistic and fatalistic attitude.

I've tried various ways to overcome it, such as meditation and connecting with loved ones, but it's hard to see any progress when the darkness feels so overwhelming. I guess I'll just have to keep trying and hope that someday things will get better."

Event:
...

The main event in the post is the loss of a significant other, which has led to feelings of depression, debt, and isolation. The author mentions losing their girlfriend of 4 years, falling into debt, and feeling unsupported by their friends. These events have had a negative impact on the author's mental health and financial stability.
Post:
"I feel like my whole life is falling apart. I lost my girlfriend of 4 years, and now I'm drowning in debt. I don't even have the support of my friends. It seems like everything I touch turns to disaster. I'm starting to think that I'm just not meant to be happy."

This post exhibits a Global Attributional Style because it takes a specific event (losing a significant other) and extrapolates it to the individual's entire life. The author assumes that one negative event will have a ripple effect, causing everything else in their life to go wrong as well. It also implies that the individual is inherently flawed or unlucky, rather than recognizing the situational nature of the event.
